page.title: 03CHANGING GRETTON SINCE 1945
page.content: In 1945 there were two bakers', six grocers', a newsagent's, a butcher's, two sweet shops and four public houses. Today both bakers', five grocers', the butcher's, the sweet shops and one of the public houses have closed. In 1945 clothes were made in a small factory but today the factory makes electrical control panels. Milk used to be delivered to the door in churns from a local farm. It was measured out and poured into jugs. Today it is delivered in bottles. Children attended the village school until they left at 14 years old; today they transfer to a secondary school at the age of 11. A railway passed through the village, with trains stopping at Gretton station, now closed. Villagers drew their water from wells and there were no sewers. Now there is mains water and a sewer.
